We had very strong double-digit growth throughout our business, and so again, we're just referring to a few retailers where we took our provision.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then you gave us some nice color on Games and Puzzles and MAGIC and it looks like MAGIC with the release in April versus the first quarter release last year had some tough comps. Just wondering a couple things in Games and P
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then you gave us some nice color on Games and Puzzles and MAGIC and it looks like MAGIC with the release in April versus the first quarter release last year had some tough comps. Just wondering a couple things in Games and Puzzles. First, I just wanted to clarify, did MAGIC see growth in the first quarter? And also, you had a management change in that division, so I was just wondering if you could talk about the drivers behind that change and what you expect for Games and Puzzles for the rest of the year?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. If you look at our Games business, first, I think, really, very encouraging was our strong double-digit growth in POS in that category for the first quarter. And so we've really seen, both in the U.S. and around the world double-digit take away
componenttext: Yes, sure. If you look at our Games business, first, I think, really, very encouraging was our strong double-digit growth in POS in that category for the first quarter. And so we've really seen, both in the U.S. and around the world double-digit take away and growth in POS. If you look at Games within the business, we'll call it face-to-face gaming, was up a bit, but MAGIC was down in the quarter, and we've talked a lot. Hopefully, people now understand that MAGIC really is release-driven, story-driven and therefore, we'll have ups and downs that may not run seasonally as much us other brands but rather just in response to the story releases and the decks that are released. The change at MAGIC, at Wizards of the Coast was planned some time ago. Gregg had indicated his desire to go off and do some other things, and we wish him all the best. He's done a terrific job for us. He was here in Providence and Pawtucket before going to Wizard to run our Boys business and he's been here with us for several years. We're very excited about Chris Cox coming onboard, and he'll be with us starting in June. And not only is he a MAGIC: THE GATHERING player and role playing gamer overall, but he's also done some tremendous experience most recently at Microsoft. So has both the analog and digital capability and that will continue to drive us in both directions.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just finally on the -- the quarter was obviously very strong for a lot of reasons. Just wondering how much of that was attributable to the Easter shift?
componenttext: Great. And then just finally on the -- the quarter was obviously very strong for a lot of reasons. Just wondering how much of that was attributable to the Easter shift?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We definitely saw a very strong Easter for us in POS, but our Easter was actually up significantly versus prior Easter. But we've seen this continued strong POS and even after Easter this year, our POS continues to be strong. And double-digit POS is acros
componenttext: We definitely saw a very strong Easter for us in POS, but our Easter was actually up significantly versus prior Easter. But we've seen this continued strong POS and even after Easter this year, our POS continues to be strong. And double-digit POS is across every category in every geography. And I think it goes back to something we talked about in prepared remarks, and that's we -- I think that thing that you're seeing in the first quarter that's off skating our otherwise very strong Franchise Brand results is just the payments that were made a year ago for stream content in a quarter that tends to be a bit lower in overall revenue, so has a bigger impact. So if you take that out, our total Franchise Brands growth for the quarter was 9%, and you saw double-digit growth in the U.S. and high single digit growth internationally for Franchise Brands. So again, that streaming payments made a year ago just get in the way of seeing that underlying strength. And it's why you're also seeing our market share grow all around the world.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Brian, you provided your updated view on expectations for STAR WARS, which has unchanged for the year. Can you kind of run us through what the puts and takes are on how you arrive at that number for that view? And then, continuing with Boys, how does S
componenttext: So Brian, you provided your updated view on expectations for STAR WARS, which has unchanged for the year. Can you kind of run us through what the puts and takes are on how you arrive at that number for that view? And then, continuing with Boys, how does Spider-Man sit into the company's plans for MARVEL in 2016?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look at the full year for STAR WARS in the calendar, clearly, Home Entertainment has just broken for THE FORCE AWAKENS. Obviously, we know the kind of contribution that will make to boys-oriented business for the next several quarters. Then
componenttext: Yes. So if you look at the full year for STAR WARS in the calendar, clearly, Home Entertainment has just broken for THE FORCE AWAKENS. Obviously, we know the kind of contribution that will make to boys-oriented business for the next several quarters. Then we transition in the fall toward Rogue One. Hopefully by now, you've seen one of the early trailers, it's very exciting and clearly a story a STAR WARS story that is very relevant to global fans, both new and old. And we'll transition to the Rogue One product. But of course, still the classic products, both from Force Awakens and classic original STAR WARS products will continue to sell. We also have a continued strong emphasis on the fan economy and fan-oriented product, which continues throughout the year. And you'll see that reflected. We're seeing it reflected in our business presently, and that's, I think, how you look at the calendarization of STAR WARS for this year. In terms of the MARVEL business, I think the interesting thing here is we do have of will be coming up in Captain America: Civil War. Hopefully, you've seen the materials there, but it's clearly a full array of all of our favorite characters from the MARVEL universe. Interestingly, the timing of the merchandising of that is a month later this year that it was a year ago, and so that does have an impact on the first quarter's MARVEL business as we time. Just happens to be the the shelf safe dates are a month later this year than a year ago although the movie dates are roughly the same. And we'll roll into Captain America: Civil War, which as I said is a full array of characters, including some of our favorites like the character you mentioned. And then, of course, we get into '17, and we do have the Spider-Man movie.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the my second question is, Brian, back in February, you had said that you expected Partner revenues to be closer to that 25% range higher-than-historical, around 20%. Partner Brands came in stronger than franchise, although there's a bit of a to
componenttext: Okay. And the my second question is, Brian, back in February, you had said that you expected Partner revenues to be closer to that 25% range higher-than-historical, around 20%. Partner Brands came in stronger than franchise, although there's a bit of a tough comp in Entertainment and Licensing. But overall, royalty rate was also up a tiny bit. Could you share with us whether your guidance for full year of Partner Brands being still at the higher end of that 20% -- 20%, 25% range in royalty rates coming down as a percentage of sales for the full year? Has that kind of guidance or expectations changed?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, it hasn't change. Our guidance is very much the same. In fact, if you look at that percent of revenues, our royalties were only up 0.1% in the quarter versus a year ago, so a very small change. The other element, as we've said, the Partner Brands
componenttext: Yes. No, it hasn't change. Our guidance is very much the same. In fact, if you look at that percent of revenues, our royalties were only up 0.1% in the quarter versus a year ago, so a very small change. The other element, as we've said, the Partner Brands even in the first quarter where you have lower absolute revenues and the impact were only up slightly above the 25% number that we've given at the high end of the range. So again, over the 4 quarters, we still expect it to be at the high end of the 20% to 25% range.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. So absent the Licensing Entertainment Licensing tough comps, of that one off payment, you still expect Franchise Brands to grow at a higher rate versus Partner?
componenttext: That's helpful. So absent the Licensing Entertainment Licensing tough comps, of that one off payment, you still expect Franchise Brands to grow at a higher rate versus Partner?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's a very hard -- we're looking at the numbers. If you take the Top 10 brands of our company at this moment in the quarter, 6 of the Top 10 brands of our company are Franchise Brands. And the top brand in our company still in the first qua
componenttext: Well, I think it's a very hard -- we're looking at the numbers. If you take the Top 10 brands of our company at this moment in the quarter, 6 of the Top 10 brands of our company are Franchise Brands. And the top brand in our company still in the first quarter is NERF. So I think the portfolio management, the teams are executing is quite strong. It's certainly a complement of Franchise Brands, at Partner Brands revenues, so the other 4 brands within the Top 10 are Partner Brands. But that's a great combination and our strongest brand, top brand of the quarter is still NERF. And that combination allows us to continue to provide that guidance to you about royalties and about Partner Brands as a percent of revenue for the year.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from the line of Stephanie Wissink with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from the line of Stephanie Wissink with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is just related to the profit growth versus the sales growth, which is a factor of threefold in this quarter, really outstanding. Curious, Deb, if you can share with us how we should think about that over the next couple of quarters, the next
componenttext: My question is just related to the profit growth versus the sales growth, which is a factor of threefold in this quarter, really outstanding. Curious, Deb, if you can share with us how we should think about that over the next couple of quarters, the next couple of years. I think at Toy Fair, you indicated your margin targets for the [indiscernible] are roughly flattish, but couple hundred basis points of expansion the first quarter. I'm just curious if that has changed the way you're thinking about the 4 [ph] year, the next couple of years?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think based on our -- we talked a little bit about the fact that the first quarter is a lot of small numbers for us, but what we're seeing is the improvement in our margins that we did say at year-end and at Toy Fair that we believe were sustainable
componenttext: So I think based on our -- we talked a little bit about the fact that the first quarter is a lot of small numbers for us, but what we're seeing is the improvement in our margins that we did say at year-end and at Toy Fair that we believe were sustainable and expandable overtime, particularly as we ramp some of the new brands and gain more operating profit for it. So the one item we did want to point out was the bad debt that was about unusual for us, while we wont exclude it, it was the first one that we've encountered as we've expanded, particularly into Emerging Markets. And we do have some high-risk accounts, but we manage those very closely and do have reserves where we deem them appropriate. But overall, our margins have grown in all of our segments, with the exception of Entertainment and Licensing. And again, that streaming revenue because of the profitability of it has a big impact. But we do continue to believe that based on our current estimates that the guidance that we gave in February, it still holds.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext: And then just one follow up, Deb, on the inventory. I think you mentioned, excluding currency up 41% year-over-year. I'm wondering if you be willing to just eliminate the non comparables for Princess. I'd imagined there's some ramp inventory there for Princess. Is it more consistent with sales, if you back that out? I mean, just look at it in the comparable basis?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think as we look at our inventory overall, you have identified a big piece of it. I mean, we're really ramping up for the business we see in the year ahead.
componenttext: Yes. I think as we look at our inventory overall, you have identified a big piece of it. I mean, we're really ramping up for the business we see in the year ahead.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext: If you look where inventory is, Steph, it's really nicely spread, and it does follow our sales curves globally, so you get about 1/3 of the inventory increase in the U.S. and the other 2/3 out internationally as we're going region for region.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think when you you said one of the keywords, which is clearly first quarter is a transitional quarter. We said that all along. Having said that, the teams have done -- our teams at Hasbro has done a fantastic job of launching the brand beautiful p
componenttext: Well, I think when you you said one of the keywords, which is clearly first quarter is a transitional quarter. We said that all along. Having said that, the teams have done -- our teams at Hasbro has done a fantastic job of launching the brand beautiful products, and it's been well received by consumers and the early take away is quite good. We are ramping this business, and we continue to believe that as we move forward, as we expand in revenues, we'll continue to improve our operating margin overtime there. So I would say that our guidance for what we want to achieve is being achieved, and we're on track for our expectations for Princess.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then if we just look at STAR WARS, is there anything that guys learned from last year's movie that you're planning to implement for this coming year's release?
componenttext: Great. And then if we just look at STAR WARS, is there anything that guys learned from last year's movie that you're planning to implement for this coming year's release?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, that was great for us to be able to have a major entertainment initiative in fourth quarter. It's great to build to spread at the entertainment initiatives across our portfolio now almost 12 months a year and that will continue to be the ca
componenttext: Well, clearly, that was great for us to be able to have a major entertainment initiative in fourth quarter. It's great to build to spread at the entertainment initiatives across our portfolio now almost 12 months a year and that will continue to be the case as we have more and more partners and our own brands launching new story-led initiatives throughout each year. That consumers certainly responded in kind, and it gives us great courage to look at new windows for new launches, and we'll track similar to last year, kind of a similar tempo and template this year as we have a fall set date for Rogue One product and that will roll into holiday-oriented movie. But again, the teams are constantly picking up on new insights, and we're using those to the advantage of customers and consumers.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, on Girls, can you help us better understand how the segment performed, excluding the Disney PRINCESS piece? And then the follow up to that, how do we think about the transition of that property into your business? Should we think of 1Q as kind of a
componenttext: Brian, on Girls, can you help us better understand how the segment performed, excluding the Disney PRINCESS piece? And then the follow up to that, how do we think about the transition of that property into your business? Should we think of 1Q as kind of a disproportionate beneficiary given the fact that it represents the initial shipping window for that property?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you look at it, clearly, in quarter were typically lower revenues, it does have a disproportional impact as you grow throughout the year, your revenues grow across the board. We had a number of our Girls brands that performed well and grew in the
componenttext: Well, if you look at it, clearly, in quarter were typically lower revenues, it does have a disproportional impact as you grow throughout the year, your revenues grow across the board. We had a number of our Girls brands that performed well and grew in the quarter, so we saw some great growth from some of what we would call our Challenger brands, including FurReal Friends, BABY ALIVE and EASY BAKE and then MY LITTLE PONY, as I said, the brand overall was up. The only place that it had an impact where it flattens the result is because of the streaming revenues that were assigned to the purchase of MY LITTLE PONY programming and LITTLEST PET SHOP programming a year ago. So we had one brand in there that we're restaging for the fall, which is NERF REBELLE and clearly, the brand is down at this moment as we restage and get reoriented around that brand for the second half of the year. And again, PET SHOP had very strong results in several territories, including the U.S. and Canada, and we're beginning to make the shift, the change and evolution of that brand out internationally and overtime, we would expect that brand to see more positive momentum overall.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext: Great. On Games, I just want to make sure I understand the comment that you made. So shipments were flat in constant currency, but POS was up double digits? Did I hear that correctly?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext: It is. A strong double digits, yes.

componenttext: So is that gap  entirely attributable to the MAGIC shift in to [indiscernible] into?

componenttext: No, I don't, I don't. We have lots of puts and takes. We have a lot of interested in the brand that were up in the quarter Our segment -- a lot of the brands within our family-oriented segment were up, including LIFE and YAHTZEE and several other brands. Obviously, PIE FACE continue to be a strong contributor. DUEL MASTERS within the YAHTZEE business was up. As I said overall face-to-face gaming was up a bit in the quarter and I do think you have coming off of a very strong fourth quarter, you still have product in the market and very strong POS, both in the U.S. and Internationally for Games.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. One last one for you, Brian. If you can comment on help of the Toy category as we enter 2016. Again, category has been relatively flat for a while and seems to be going to the survival. What are you hearing premier retailers, both brick-and-mo
componenttext: Understood. One last one for you, Brian. If you can comment on help of the Toy category as we enter 2016. Again, category has been relatively flat for a while and seems to be going to the survival. What are you hearing premier retailers, both brick-and-mortar and online? Are they believers in the sustainably? Are they dedicating more resource to the category?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say, yes to really everything you've said. Well, remember last year, we had a very robust growth in U.S. and globally, developed economies as well as Emerging Markets in the Toy industry. So I would say this is the second year of strong grow
componenttext: Well, I would say, yes to really everything you've said. Well, remember last year, we had a very robust growth in U.S. and globally, developed economies as well as Emerging Markets in the Toy industry. So I would say this is the second year of strong growth year-to-date. We're seeing high single digit growth rates, both in developed economies like U.S. and also throughout Europe. Retailers are very excited about the category as we continue to have more story-driven brands, more integrated play brands and more innovation in the category. Overall, POS was very strong as I said, but as we've noted before, online POS was even stronger and many additional retailers that have been historically BRIC retailers are doing a very good job in omni-channel, and so we saw great growth for several online retailers, both pure play as well as omni-channel retailers. So I would say overall, the state of the industry is quite strong and our indications are from projections that will remain strong for the next several years.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext: Can you guys discuss if there are any pockets of excess inventory outside of EQUESTRIA GIRLS? I know you were filling the channels for a lot of products but that seems to be the only product that was called out maybe not performing exactly how you would expect it.

componenttext: As I mentioned, NERF REBELLE, clearly, we're restaging that part of the NERF brand. Had some inventory carried over, and we're restaging it for the second half. We got a great responsible retailers to the new lineup of NERF REBELLE products for the second half of the year and our expectations is the brand should sell-through some remaining inventory in the first half. But I would say those are really the 2 brands. The only other one, and I almost -- we've talked about this over a number of calls this FURBY. We do have some remaining FURBY less hopefully quarter of FURBY headwinds, if you will. We're reselling out some remaining FURBY up against a year ago.

componenttext: Well, Brazil, continues to be strong growth. It just obviously, you're having a currency impact so absent FX, Brazil -- the underlying growth in Brazil are brands in Brazil are for performing. Clearly, we are seeing growth in regions like Mexico, but I don't know, Deb, you want to comment on the environment?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, our business continues to be good. As of late, the real has done a bit better as all currencies have and we did say in our prepared remarks particularly if they euro holds up the way it's trading right now that will have a positive impact on our expec
componenttext: No, our business continues to be good. As of late, the real has done a bit better as all currencies have and we did say in our prepared remarks particularly if they euro holds up the way it's trading right now that will have a positive impact on our expectations for foreign exchange impact us for the full year. But we continue to see the market in Brazil being good and consumer take away being good as well.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of items, my apologies there. Staying on the currency, Deb, and just going on those related questions. A little more color you said if rates stay where they are, you talked about the $100 million reference debt to be substantially better. An
componenttext: Just a couple of items, my apologies there. Staying on the currency, Deb, and just going on those related questions. A little more color you said if rates stay where they are, you talked about the $100 million reference debt to be substantially better. Any more color on the revenue operating profits again assuming rates stay were they are today? And then you guys put on adding additional hedging in Q1 that may be benefiting that now that the rates have moved?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We hedged throughout the year, so we probably did put some hedges on in the first quarter. Overall, from a hedging standpoint, we hedged about 75% our product costs last year, we're about hedged the same amount this year. So we try to make sure we stay at
componenttext: We hedged throughout the year, so we probably did put some hedges on in the first quarter. Overall, from a hedging standpoint, we hedged about 75% our product costs last year, we're about hedged the same amount this year. So we try to make sure we stay at a similar level. So it's hard to tell if rates are going to go. I think if you look at all the experts are saying, they expect the dollar strengthened. However, we're not seeing that particularly against the euro right now. So if rates stay the way they are, we did put a chart in our earnings presentation so you could see the makeup of our revenues by currency in the first quarter and depending on what your expectations are for FX rates,we can just kind of look at it that way. But we're kind of hitting the point where we're getting comparable FX rates to last year in certain regions.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I guess, from a color standpoint, you're talking $10 million, $20 million difference versus $100 million that you talked about in February?
componenttext: Okay. I guess, from a color standpoint, you're talking $10 million, $20 million difference versus $100 million that you talked about in February?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've got $30 million almost already in, so as you look at the rest of the year, I mean, if the euro continues to stay strong, it's actually trading above levels it was trading out last year. So that could significantly change our expectations for t
componenttext: Well, we've got $30 million almost already in, so as you look at the rest of the year, I mean, if the euro continues to stay strong, it's actually trading above levels it was trading out last year. So that could significantly change our expectations for the year. But again, it's just too early to tell.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then, any color, Brian, Deb, that you feel comfortable giving? I know part of it is sensitive with specific streaming contract, but as far as the swing factor, the streaming contract in TRANSFORMERS together, how it impact Entertainment Li
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then, any color, Brian, Deb, that you feel comfortable giving? I know part of it is sensitive with specific streaming contract, but as far as the swing factor, the streaming contract in TRANSFORMERS together, how it impact Entertainment Licensing, was that the majority of the swing there? I mean can we strike all of it? Or any additional color you could break down?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was I think between the 2, between the fact that we're coming off. Remember, we've said before that if we do licenses, we get paid the following quarter. So obviously, in first quarter of '15, we were collecting royalties for the fourth quarter '1
componenttext: Yes, it was I think between the 2, between the fact that we're coming off. Remember, we've said before that if we do licenses, we get paid the following quarter. So obviously, in first quarter of '15, we were collecting royalties for the fourth quarter '14 in TRANSFORMERS. And then, of course, we had the streaming deal, and I think both are exacerbated by the fact that you're dealing in a typically lower revenues quarter, so more of an impact in percentage terms. And you're right, I think that's the bulk of the change.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttextpreview: Particularly, where we're seeing some impact to certain retailers is in our Emerging Markets. I did already comment that Brazil continues to be a strong market for us right now and do well. So other markets, not Brazil.
componenttext: Particularly, where we're seeing some impact to certain retailers is in our Emerging Markets. I did already comment that Brazil continues to be a strong market for us right now and do well. So other markets, not Brazil.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext: The other thing I wanted to -- I d just like to note because we do have some big retailers. We're not talking about the bigger retailers that have are presented significant partners for us and growth engines for us in those areas. So Deb in Russia, PB Kids in Brazil, both continue to be strong, continue to be strong retail is really talking about some retailers that we're not among our top retailers but clearly retailers we've been selling to.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And lastly, Brian, China. It would appear that, that has been continues to be a pretty good growth driver for you. Correct me if I'm wrong there. And then, just especially your e-commerce outlook in China and how that is trending over
componenttext: That's very helpful. And lastly, Brian, China. It would appear that, that has been continues to be a pretty good growth driver for you. Correct me if I'm wrong there. And then, just especially your e-commerce outlook in China and how that is trending over the last 12 months, 18 months, whatever period here, and then how do you see that growth curve here over the balance of '16?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, clearly, e-com in China is one of the key themes for future growth given the we're getting growth today future growth is even stronger as we orient our company and our business to e-com globally but particularly, in China, it was a great this interm
componenttext: Well, clearly, e-com in China is one of the key themes for future growth given the we're getting growth today future growth is even stronger as we orient our company and our business to e-com globally but particularly, in China, it was a great this intermediary for that market, allows us to get to the vast majority of consumers, and it's an area of focus for us. China has shown some good growth, but remember, our Asia Pacific business overall showed good growth, so be on China, which is quite heartening to see country for country in Korea, some great growth in Southeast Asia as well as Australia and New Zealand business. So China continues to be, both a short and long-term opportunity for us. We do have a great array of brands that are beloved in China and particularly brand like TRANSFORMERS, and we'll continue to build the business. But I think e-com one is one of the focus of our company globally and also a specific e-com focus in China.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext: Deb, just to clarify on the tax rate. It looks like you came in around 21%. Should we still continue with the for 26.5% or 27% for the remainder of the year?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The adjustments that got us down to that 21% were just discrete items. And our underlying tax rate, we still -- are still in the range of 26.5% to 27% that we talked about at year-end.
componenttext: The adjustments that got us down to that 21% were just discrete items. And our underlying tax rate, we still -- are still in the range of 26.5% to 27% that we talked about at year-end.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just secondly, following up on MY LITTLE PONY, what is the entertainment schedule look like this year and next? And how do you view that brand going forward?
componenttext: Great. And then just secondly, following up on MY LITTLE PONY, what is the entertainment schedule look like this year and next? And how do you view that brand going forward?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. MY LITTLE PONY next season is just launching now and rolling out around the world. It's the sixth season for the brand. And theme this year is all about exploring EQUESTRIA and it ties together with lots of the initiatives that we have across the com
componenttext: Yes. MY LITTLE PONY next season is just launching now and rolling out around the world. It's the sixth season for the brand. And theme this year is all about exploring EQUESTRIA and it ties together with lots of the initiatives that we have across the company. We have very robust plans on multi-categories for MY LITTLE PONY throughout this year, brand-new toys and games products, but also we've seen some really wonderful product in our consumer products Licensing business and apparel that's out internationally. In the U.K., very strong results in several categories of product setting all around the world in tune with that theme, and that will roll into 2017. And then, as you know, for fall of 2017, November, we have our first animated feature film that will be distributed by Lionsgate in the MY LITTLE PONY movie. So we'll have television entertainment, streaming entertainment across a number of different over-the-top providers. Kids can find entertainment both short form and long form and then they can also find entertainment and digital games with some new digital games that we'll launch, including one new MY LITTLE PONY digital game launching from Backflip Studios. We continue to have a game from Gameloft throughout the year, so storytelling across a number of different dimensions and continue to feel very good about the brand. And as I've mentioned, the new EQUESTRIA GIRLS line and launches is going off quite well with the new mini doll segment.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext: Forgive me if you've already gone through this, but your U.S. and Canada business, you had great revenue growth, 28%. The margin increased, but not as much as revenue growth. And I'm just curious, what expense items, particularly of note where that sort of drove the margin below your revenue growth? And then secondly, looking at STAR WARS, where POS consistent through the quarter, or was there a big shipment that occurred just prior to the home entertainment release?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, the operating profit in the U.S. business increased 89%. So the revenues were up 28%, operating profit was up 89%, and I'm not sure, the operating profit margin in the quarter was 17.7% up against 12% a year ago. So I just want to ma
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, the operating profit in the U.S. business increased 89%. So the revenues were up 28%, operating profit was up 89%, and I'm not sure, the operating profit margin in the quarter was 17.7% up against 12% a year ago. So I just want to make sure we're ...

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, sorry, I misspoke. What was it that essentially allowed you to get that margin of 570 basis points?
componenttext: No, sorry, I misspoke. What was it that essentially allowed you to get that margin of 570 basis points?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, it's obviously the revenue increases and a great portfolio of franchise growth as well as Partner group. So again, I've mentioned that the Top 10 brands of our company, we have 6 of our 7 Franchise Brands and then some Partner Brands. It's that
componenttext: Yes, well, it's obviously the revenue increases and a great portfolio of franchise growth as well as Partner group. So again, I've mentioned that the Top 10 brands of our company, we have 6 of our 7 Franchise Brands and then some Partner Brands. It's that blend that should allow you to understand how we intend to improve operating margins over time, how our Partner Brands will remain at the top end of the 20% to 25% of revenues and why royalty should be roughly in line with our guidance for the year.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then STAR WARS?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: STAR WARS. No, we've been shifting STAR WARS throughout. We came off a very strong movie. Remember, the movie has continued to play in theaters so we continue to ship product is more and more people saw the movie. And then of course, there are all kinds o
componenttext: STAR WARS. No, we've been shifting STAR WARS throughout. We came off a very strong movie. Remember, the movie has continued to play in theaters so we continue to ship product is more and more people saw the movie. And then of course, there are all kinds of initiatives around the home entertainment windows, what those will continue. So I wouldn't say that there was one pulse of inventory into the market, but rather, very strong sell-through throughout.

So just curious how the female business for STAR WARS is doing versus prior year. And if you think that's an opportunity going forward?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext: So YOKAI is only in its first couple of months as you correctly indicate and really rolling out around the world in entertainment. So we've only really seen entertainment in the U.S. and it will go going into International markets throughout the year. And early indications are quite good, but it's still very early days. Rogue One is exciting for everyone and I think we continue to offer on array of products for all STAR WARS fans of all ages and genders and affiliations, and you'll see us continue to focus on product for everyone. And the product have been well received by everyone. And again, I think what you're seeing overall is a blending of such more historical delineation that we're really not focusing on or fostering. We're just making great products. We love the lead characters of these movies, and we're very excited about where STAR WARS is going. We also saw in the first quarter great sales of light sabers and I think light saber is going to everyone because everybody can be a Jedi.

componenttextpreview: :   Good morning, and welcome to the Hasbro First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time.At this time, I'd like to turn the call ov
componenttext:
:   Good morning, and welcome to the Hasbro First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time.
At this time, I'd like to turn the call over to Ms. Debbie Hancock, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Thank you, and good morning, everyone. Joining me this morning are Brian Goldner, Hasbro's Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Deb Thomas, Hasbro's Chief Financial Officer. Today, we will begin with Brian and Deb providing commen
componenttext:
:  
  Thank you, and good morning, everyone. Joining me this morning are Brian Goldner, Hasbro's Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Deb Thomas, Hasbro's Chief Financial Officer. 
Today, we will begin with Brian and Deb providing commentary on the company's performance, and then we will take your questions.
Our first quarter earnings release was issued this morning and is available on our website. Additionally, presentation slides containing information covered in today's earnings release and call are also available on our site. The press release and presentation include information regarding non-GAAP financial measures. Please note that whenever we discuss earnings per share, or EPS, we are referring to earnings per diluted share.
Before we begin, I would like to remind you that during this call and the question-and-answer session that follows, members of Hasbro management may make forward-looking statements concerning management's expectations, goals, objectives and similar matters. There are many factors that could cause actual results or events to differ materially from the anticipated results or other expectations expressed in these forward-looking statements. Some of those factors are set forth in our Annual Report on Form 10-K, our most recent 10-Q in today's press release and in our other public disclosures. We undertake no obligation to update any forward-looking statements made today to reflect events or circumstances occurring after the date of this call.
I would now like to introduce Brian Goldner. Brian?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Thank you, Debbie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. First quarter's revenue, operating profit and net earnings growth reflected a commitment to our strategy and the inherent benefits of focusing on Hasbro's Franchise Bran
componenttext:
:  
  Thank you, Debbie. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. First quarter's revenue, operating profit and net earnings growth reflected a commitment to our strategy and the inherent benefits of focusing on Hasbro's Franchise Brands, key strategic Partner Brands and our ability to execute around the blueprint.
The global Hasbro teams continue to perform at a very high level, delivering innovative brand experiences informed by global consumer insights and supported by compelling storytelling. We are building deep and relevant brand connections with consumers across broad demographics and geographies. 
First quarter revenues grew 16% and 20% absent FX, driven by Hasbro Franchise Brands, Partner Brands and strength across geographies. Hasbro's global teams delivered in an extremely strong quarter, with double-digit revenue and operating profit growth in the U.S. and Canada and International segments.
Internationally, we grew revenues despite the foreign exchange environment, with strong gains in many developed economies.
When adjusted for foreign exchange, we posted double-digit revenue growth in all major geographic regions. Emerging market revenues increased 6% absent FX, and we continue to expect these markets to grow revenues double digits absent FX for 2016. 
While consumer demand remains robust, we are beginning to see an impact on some retailers from the ongoing economic challenges.
Global point-of-sale increased 27% in the quarter, behind double-digit growth in all major regions: North America, Europe, Latin America and Asia Pacific and double-digit growth in both Toys and Games.
In the U.S., point-of-sale increased double digits in all categories: Boys, Girls, Games and Preschool with growth in Franchise and Partner Brands.
In addition, according to NPD, through the first 2 months of the year, we continued to gain share in nearly every major market.
Overall, Franchise Brand revenues grew in the quarter. In total, Toy and Game revenues for Franchise Brands increased 9% absent FX, increasing 12% in the U.S. and Canada segment and 6% in the International segment.
The first quarter had several unique and expected comparison challenges within the Franchise Brands, which don't change our positive outlook for the full year.
Q1 was a tough comparison within the Entertainment and Licensing category. Franchise Brand revenues in the segment declined this year versus last year when we recorded revenue for a multi-year digital streaming deal. The agreement includes MY LITTLE PONY, LITTLEST PET SHOP and TRANSFORMERS programming. This segment also had tough comparisons in consumer products and film revenues related to the 2014 TRANSFORMERS movie recorded last year. 
TRANSFORMERS Toy and Game revenues were also down versus a very strong first quarter of last year when it benefited from the movie. Franchise Brand POS in the quarter was up high single digits globally and double digits in the U.S., more than overcoming the negative TRANSFORMERS comparison.
Within our Franchise Brands, NERF and PLAY-DOH continue to deliver strong growth. New innovations from NERF, including Modulus and Rival are performing well, and 2016 marks their first full year in the market.
PLAY-DOH continues to drive growth in play sets and compounds. This year, we are launching an entirely new system of play with PLAY-DOH Town that is now available in the U.S. and rolling out internationally throughout 2016.
MY LITTLE PONY grew in the U.S. and Canada segment and absent FX in the International segment. We continue to deliver innovative new products, strong licensing programs and compelling entertainment, including the 6 season of MY LITTLE PONY: Friendship is Magic, which began airing March 26.
In addition, the launch of the new EQUESTRIA GIRLS mini doll segment is off to a strong start. We are working through some retail inventory within EQUESTRIA GIRLS, but we are optimistic about the initial consumer reaction to our new offering and the overall outlook for MY LITTLE PONY globally.
As I mentioned, TRANSFORMERS revenue represented the most significant decline within our Franchise Brands for the quarter. New entertainment began late in the first quarter of this year, with the second season of TRANSFORMERS: Robots in Disguise on Cartoon Network in the U.S. and currently rolling out internationally.
Machinima and Hasbro are unveiling all new entertainment targeting the older TRANSFORMERS' fan later this year. We're also actively developing the next chapter of the TRANSFORMERS theatrical stories. 
In February, Paramount pictures dated TRANSFORMERS 5 for release on June 23, 2017, with 2 additional TRANSFORMERS films planned for June of 2018 and 2019. We have global teams of talented individuals working on this multi-year theatrical entertainment and innovation slate.
Overall, Games' revenue was down slightly in the quarter and flat absent FX.
PIE FACE continues to be in high demand. We also saw growth in our digital gaming licensing, including YAHTZEE, which is being driven by our mobile gaming license with Scopely.
DUEL MASTERS, a Japanese trading card game, also contributed to growth in the quarter. We are investing to build great gaming experiences in both face-to-face and digital play environments.
Our outlook for MAGIC: THE GATHERING remains positive. The release schedule fluctuates and revenue timing is story driven, but it is effectively driving engagement with players. We shipped the first set in the Shadows Over Innistrad block on April 8 versus the first quarter release last year. It is off to a fabulous start with prerelease attendance up 20%, and this validates our change to a 2-set block. MAGIC recently achieved the milestone of 1 million active players in our organized play system.
We also have 65,000 players who play in premier events stream to Esports audiences. This is an area we're investing in to both grow the number of events and the player base.
The team at Wizards of the Coast is doing great work to foster both analog and digital play for the MAGIC community. We're very pleased to have Chris Cox from Microsoft joining us as President of Wizards of the Coast. 
As we announced last week, Greg Leeds is leaving Hasbro. We are grateful for his contributions, and wish him the best in his new endeavors. 
The first quarter also benefits from the strength of our Partner Brands. Retail and consumer demand for STAR WARS remained very high, and at this early stage of the year, we continue to believe 2016 revenues could be in line with last year.
STAR WARS: THE FORCE AWAKENS was recently released in home entertainment and Rogue One: A Star Wars Story is scheduled for release on December 16. 
The first quarter also marked the on-shelf date for Hasbro's line of DISNEY PRINCESS and Disney frozen fashion dolls and small dolls. Initial consumer reaction has been very positive, and our approach of offering the entire range of DISNEY PRINCESS is resonating.
New content and the all new characters of the Moana and Elena of Avalor will further support our innovative products this year.
In addition, Marvel's Captain America: Civil War will be in theaters on May 6. We have a robust line and strong planned retail promotional activity supporting this film.
The first quarter was a good start to the year, but we know there is a lot of the year left to deliver. For 2016 and beyond, we have an innovative line of both Hasbro brands and Partner Brands, and we are investing to deliver the best experiences to retailers and consumers globally. This includes continued strategic investment and further development of our capabilities around the brand blueprint, including in storytelling, digital gaming and our consumer products licensing efforts.
I'll now turn the call over to Deb. Deb?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. The first quarter was a very good quarter for Hasbro. The strength of our results reflected the continued momentum in our business and strong execution by our global teams. We grew revenues, operating p
componenttext:
:  
  Thank you, Brian, and good morning, everyone. The first quarter was a very good quarter for Hasbro. The strength of our results reflected the continued momentum in our business and strong execution by our global teams. We grew revenues, operating profit and earnings, despite the continued negative impact from foreign exchange and challenging economic environments in some International markets.
We returned $93.2 million in cash to shareholders and ended the quarter, with a very strong balance sheet, well positioned to support our 2016 growth outlook.
Looking at our segments for the first quarter 2016, revenues in the U.S. and Canada segment increased 28%. The Boys, Girls and Preschool categories posted revenue growth, while the Games category declined slightly. Hasbro Franchise Brand revenues increased, and Partner Brands further contributed to growth, with revenue increases in STAR WARS, DISNEY PRINCESS, FROZEN and DESCENDANTS as well as YOKAI WATCH. 
U.S. point-of-sale posted solid double-digit growth in all categories, and retail inventory continued to be a very good quality. Operating profit in the U.S. and Canada segment increased 89%, reflecting higher revenues, partially offset by higher expense levels.
International segment revenues grew 13%. Excluding the negative $26.7 million impact from foreign exchange, International segment revenues increased 22%.
Revenue in the segment grew in all 4 product categories: Boys, Girls, Games and Preschool. 
Franchise Brand revenues were down slightly as reported, but grew absent FX.  Partner Brands were also positive contributors, including STAR WARS, DISNEY PRINCESS and FROZEN.
Operating profit in the segment increased 50% to $2.9 million. Profit improvement on higher revenues was partially offset by increased expenses year-over-year.
During the quarter, we also took a $13.8 million bad debt provision for potentially uncollectible receivables. This was the first significant provision taken since we began our expansion in 2008 into more International territories, notably emerging markets.
Overall, we feel we've taken the appropriate risks and managed our higher risk accounts very closely.
Current exchange rates in certain regions have changed favorably since the beginning of this year. Although the euro has strengthened, other currencies continue to weaken in the quarter.
For the full year, we forecasted an approximate $100 million negative impact from foreign exchange compared to 2015. If rates, in particular, the euro stay favorable, that impact would be much lower.
Entertainment and Licensing segment revenues declined 30%. In the first quarter of last year, the segment benefited from a multi-year digital streaming deal for Hasbro Studios television programming.  
Consumer product Licensing and Entertainment revenues also declined in the quarter, most notably from the difficult comparison with last year's TRANSFORMERS movie-related merchandise and revenues.
Licensing revenue is generally recorded in rears [ph] and last year's first quarter reflected the holiday 2014 TRANSFORMERS movie-related revenue. 
Segment operating profit declined 67%.  In addition to lower revenue, we continue to make investments in our consumer products team digital gaming and storytelling to drive future growth in these higher profit margin revenue sources. These are strategically important capabilities, which truly differentiate Hasbro's brands with both consumers and retailers.
Turning to overall expenses. Higher revenues drove improved expense leverage and a 270 basis point increase in operating profit margin for the quarter. 
We continue to see growth in Partner Brands, which drive a lower cost of sales to revenue and higher royalty to sales ratios. Both measures were close to flat with last year levels, as cost of sales for the quarter were 34.9% of revenues and royalties totaled 8.4%.
Product development dollar growth reflects continued investment in innovation across our brand portfolio, including Franchise, Partner and new brands. Advertising remained approximately flat as a percentage of sales, and intangible amortization declined, reflecting some of our digital gaming assets becoming fully amortized in the second quarter of last year.
Program production cost amortization was also down in the quarter. In the first quarter of last year, this line reflected the higher revenue and associated amortization with our streaming deal for Hasbro programming.
SD&A in the quarter was down as a percent of revenues. SD&A dollars increased 12%, primarily due to investments around our brand blueprint, bad debt and higher compensation expense.
Our first quarter results support our ability to sustain and grow operating profit levels over time. While achieving this, we continue to make incremental investments in our brands, including in the digital ecosystem for MAGIC: THE GATHERING, in our IT systems to drive efficiencies and enhance innovation and in our talent and capabilities to execute our brand blueprint.
In the first quarter, the strength of our business enabled us to deliver operating profit expansion, while investing for future growth.
Turning to our results the low operating profit for the quarter. Other expense was $2.7 million versus income of $4.7 million last year. Increased profits associated with our 40% share of the operating income in the Discovery Family Channel, combined with higher interest income on our investments, was more than offset by larger losses from foreign exchange transactions.
The underlying tax rate was 26.5%, down from 27% last year and essentially in line with 26.4% for the full year 2015.
Diluted earnings per share were $0.38 compared to $0.21 last year. Our balance sheet remains strong. Cash totaled $1.1 billion at quarter end. We generated $294 million in operating cash flow during the quarter and $531 million over the past 12 months.
During the first quarter, we returned $93.2 million to shareholders: $57.4 million in dividends and $35.8 million in share repurchases. 
Our May 16 dividend payment will be the first quarter at the higher dividend rate of $0.51 per share, which the board increased 11% in February.
Receivables at quarter end were up 19% versus the 16% growth in revenues and, DSOs increased 2 days to 73 days. 
Absent the impact of foreign exchange, receivables increased approximately 23% versus 20% revenue growth absent FX.
Overall, our accounts receivable are in good condition, and collections continue to be strong. 
Inventories increased 36% versus last year. Adjusting for negative foreign exchange impact, inventory increased 41%, reflecting the new businesses we're supporting, the timing of entertainment and our outlook for 2016.
Overall, we believe we have the right amount and quality of inventory at retail and at Hasbro to meet our growth expectations for the year.
Throughout the first quarter, we maintained and improved upon the higher level of performance we delivered last year. While we have a great deal of the year left to go, we're well positioned to capitalize on the innovation and entertainment driving our brands.
Brian and I are now happy to take your questions.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Yes, this is in -- yes, a good point. I mean this isn't consumer related. We're not talking about the takeaways, and we talked about the double-digit growth in POS across all of our regions in the quarter. We had very strong double-digit growth thr
componenttext:
:  
  Yes, this is in -- yes, a good point. I mean this isn't consumer related. We're not talking about the takeaways, and we talked about the double-digit growth in POS across all of our regions in the quarter. We had very strong double-digit growth throughout our business, and so again, we're just referring to a few retailers where we took our provision.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Okay. That's very helpful. And then you gave us some nice color on Games and Puzzles and MAGIC, and it looks like MAGIC with the release in April versus the first quarter release last year had some tough comps. Just wondering a couple of things in
componenttext:
:  
  Okay. That's very helpful. And then you gave us some nice color on Games and Puzzles and MAGIC, and it looks like MAGIC with the release in April versus the first quarter release last year had some tough comps. Just wondering a couple of things in Games and Puzzles. First, I just wanted to clarify, did MAGIC see growth in the first quarter? And then also, you had a management change in that division, so I was just wondering if you could talk about the drivers behind that change and what you expect for Games and Puzzles for the rest of the year.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Yes, sure. If you look at our Games business, first, I think, really, very encouraging was our strong double-digit growth in POS in that category for the first quarter. And so we've really seen, both in the U.S. and around the world, double-digit t
componenttext:
:  
  Yes, sure. If you look at our Games business, first, I think, really, very encouraging was our strong double-digit growth in POS in that category for the first quarter. And so we've really seen, both in the U.S. and around the world, double-digit takeaway and growth in POS. If you look at Games within the business, we'll call it face-to-face gaming, was up a bit, but MAGIC was down in the quarter, and we've talked a lot. Hopefully, people now understand that MAGIC really is release-driven, story-driven, and therefore, we'll have ups and downs that may not run seasonally as much as other brands, but rather just in response to the story releases and the decks that are released. The change at MAGIC, at Wizards of the Coast was planned some time ago. Greg had indicated desire to go off and do some other things, and we wish him all the best. He's done a terrific job for us. He was here in Providence and Pawtucket before going to Wizards to run our Boys business, and he's been here with us for several years. We're very excited about Chris Cox coming onboard, and he'll be with us starting in June. And not only is he a MAGIC: THE GATHERING player and role playing gamer overall but he's also got some tremendous experience most recently at Microsoft. So he has both the analog and digital capability, and that will continue to drive us in both directions.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Great. And then just finally on your quarter was obviously very strong for a lot of different reasons. Just wondering how much of that was attributable to the Easter shift.
componenttext:
:  
  Great. And then just finally on your quarter was obviously very strong for a lot of different reasons. Just wondering how much of that was attributable to the Easter shift.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    We definitely saw a very strong Easter for us in POS, but our Easter was actually up significantly versus prior Easter. But we've seen this continued strong POS even after Easter this year. Our POS continues to be strong, and the double-digit POS i
componenttext:
:  
  We definitely saw a very strong Easter for us in POS, but our Easter was actually up significantly versus prior Easter. But we've seen this continued strong POS even after Easter this year. Our POS continues to be strong, and the double-digit POS is across every category in every geography. And I think it goes back to something we talked about in prepared remarks, and that's we -- I think that thing that you're seeing in the first quarter that's obfuscating our otherwise very strong Franchise Brand results. It's just the payments that were made a year ago for stream content in a quarter that tends to be a bit lower in overall revenue. So it has a bigger impact. If we take that out, our total Franchise Brands growth for the quarter was 9%, and you saw double-digit growth in the U.S. and high single digit growth internationally for Franchise Brands. So again, that streaming payments made a year ago just get in the way of seeing that underlying strength, and it's why you're also seeing our market shares grow all around the world.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Our next question comes from the line of Andrew Crum with Stifel.
componenttext:
:  
  Our next question comes from the line of Andrew Crum with Stifel.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    So Brian, you provided your updated view on expectations for STAR WARS, which is unchanged for the year. Can you kind of run us through what the puts and takes are? And how you arrive at that number for that view? And then, continuing with Boys, ho
componenttext:
:  
  So Brian, you provided your updated view on expectations for STAR WARS, which is unchanged for the year. Can you kind of run us through what the puts and takes are? And how you arrive at that number for that view? And then, continuing with Boys, how does Spider-Man sit into the company's plans for MARVEL in 2016?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Yes. So if you look at the full year for STAR WARS in the calendar, clearly, Home Entertainment has just broken for The Force Awakens. Obviously, we know the kind of contribution that will make to boys-oriented business for the next several quarter
componenttext:
:  
  Yes. So if you look at the full year for STAR WARS in the calendar, clearly, Home Entertainment has just broken for The Force Awakens. Obviously, we know the kind of contribution that will make to boys-oriented business for the next several quarters. Then we transition in the fall toward Rogue One. Hopefully, by now, you've seen one of the early trailers. It's very exciting, and clearly a story -- a STAR WARS story that is very relevant to global fans, both new and old and will transition to the Rogue One product. But of course, still the classic products, both from Force Awakens and classic original STAR WARS products will continue to sell. We also have a continued strong emphasis on the fan economy and fan-oriented product, which continues throughout the year, and you'll see that reflected. We're seeing it reflected in our business presently, and that's, I think how you look at the calendarization of STAR WARS for this year. In terms of the MARVEL business, I think the interesting thing here is we do have a movie coming up in Captain America: Civil War. Hopefully, you've seen the materials there, but it's clearly a full array of all of our favorite characters from the MARVEL Universe. Interestingly, the timing of the merchandising of that is a month later this year than it was a year ago, and so that does have an impact on the first quarter's MARVEL business as we time that just happens to be the shelf set dates are a month later this year than a year ago although the movie dates roughly the same. And we'll roll into Captain America: Civil War, which as I said is a full array of characters, including some of our favorites like the character you mentioned. And then, of course, we get into '17, and we do have the Spider-Man movie.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Brian, just go back to your last comments. Are you suggesting that you were not shipping Captain America product in the first quarter?
componenttext:
:

componenttext:

For Toys, up strong double digits; and Boys, similarly, Girls, Preschool and Games were up double digits. Our Franchise Brands in the U.S. were up double digits in POS. And we did see a very strong Easter, but we've been seeing strong weak on weak POS. And as I indicated, our strong double-digit POS has continued beyond Easter.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Okay. And the my second question is, Brian, back in February, you had said that you expected Partner revenues to be closer to that 25% range higher than historical around 20%. Partner Brands came in stronger than franchise, although there's a bit o
componenttext:
:  
  Okay. And the my second question is, Brian, back in February, you had said that you expected Partner revenues to be closer to that 25% range higher than historical around 20%. Partner Brands came in stronger than franchise, although there's a bit of a tough comp in Entertainment and Licensing. But overall, royalty rate was also up a tiny bit. Could you share with us whether your guidance for full year of Partner Brands being still at the higher end of that 20%, 25% range and royalty rates coming down as a percentage of sales for the full year? Has that kind of guidance or expectation changed?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Yes -- no, it hasn't changed. Our guidance is very much the same. In fact, if you look as a percent of revenues, our royalties were only up 0.1 percentage point in the quarter versus a year ago. So a very small change. The other element that as we'
componenttext:
:  
  Yes -- no, it hasn't changed. Our guidance is very much the same. In fact, if you look as a percent of revenues, our royalties were only up 0.1 percentage point in the quarter versus a year ago. So a very small change. The other element that as we've said, the Partner Brands, even in the first quarter where you have lower absolute revenues and the impact, were only up slightly above the 25% number that we've given at the high end of the range. So again, over the 4 quarters, we still expect it to be at the high end of the 20% to 25% range.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    That's helpful. So absent the Licensing -- Entertainment and Licensing tough comp of that one-off payment, do you still expect Franchise Brands to grow at a higher rate versus Partner?
componenttext:

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Well, I think it's a very hard thing. I was -- we're looking at the numbers and if you take the Top 10 brands of our company at this moment in the quarter, 6 of the Top 10 brands of our company are Franchise Brands. And the top brand in our company
componenttext:
:  
  Well, I think it's a very hard thing. I was -- we're looking at the numbers and if you take the Top 10 brands of our company at this moment in the quarter, 6 of the Top 10 brands of our company are Franchise Brands. And the top brand in our company still in the first quarter is NERF. So I think the portfolio management the teams are executing is quite strong. It's certainly a complement of Franchise Brands and Partner Brands revenues. So the other 4 brands within the Top 10 are Partner Brands, but that's a great combination and our strongest brand -- top brand of the quarter is still NERF. And that combination allows us to continue to provide that guidance to you about royalties and about Partner Brands as a percent of revenue for the year.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Our next question is coming from the line of Stephanie Wissink with Piper Jaffray.

  Our next question is coming from the line of Stephanie Wissink with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    My question is just related to the profit growth versus the sales growth, which is a factor of threefold in this quarter, really outstanding. Curious, Deb, if you can share with us how we should think about that over the next couple of quarters, th
componenttext:
:  
  My question is just related to the profit growth versus the sales growth, which is a factor of threefold in this quarter, really outstanding. Curious, Deb, if you can share with us how we should think about that over the next couple of quarters, the next couple of years. I think at Toy Fair, you indicated your margin targets for this year are roughly flattish, but a couple hundred basis points of expansion in the first quarter. I'm just curious if that's changed the way you're thinking about the forward year and the next couple of years.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    So I think based on our -- we talked a little bit about the fact that the first quarter is -- it's a lot of small numbers for us. But what we're seeing is the improvement in our margins that we did say at year-end and at Toy Fair that we believe we
componenttext:
:  
  So I think based on our -- we talked a little bit about the fact that the first quarter is -- it's a lot of small numbers for us. But what we're seeing is the improvement in our margins that we did say at year-end and at Toy Fair that we believe were sustainable and expandable over time, particularly as we ramp some of the new brands and gain more operating profit for it. So the one item we did want to point out was the bad debt. That was about unusual for us. While we won't exclude it, it was the first one that we've encountered as we've expanded, particularly into emerging markets. And we do have some high-risk accounts, but we manage those very closely and do have reserves, where we deem them appropriate. But overall, our margins have grown in all of our segments, with the exception of Entertainment and Licensing. And again, that streaming revenue, because of the profitability of it, has a big impact. But we do continue to believe that based on our current estimates that the guidance that we gave in February, it still holds.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    And then just one follow-up, Deb, on the inventory. I think you mentioned excluding currency up 41% year-over-year. I'm wondering if you'd be willing to just eliminate the non-comparables for PRINCESS. I'd imagine there's some ramp inventory there
componenttext:
:  
  And then just one follow-up, Deb, on the inventory. I think you mentioned excluding currency up 41% year-over-year. I'm wondering if you'd be willing to just eliminate the non-comparables for PRINCESS. I'd imagine there's some ramp inventory there for PRINCESS. Is it more consistent with sales if you back that out? I mean, just look at it on a comparable basis?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext:
:  
  Yes. I think as we look at our inventory overall, you have identified a big piece of it. I mean, we're really ramping up for the business we see in the year ahead.

componenttext:
:  
  If you look where inventory is, Steph, it's really nicely spread. And it does follow our sales curves globally. So you get about 1/3 of the inventory increase in the U.S. and the other 2/3 out internationally as we're growing region-for-region.

componenttext:
:  
This is actually Fred on for Greg. Just wondering if you guys could give a little bit color on the DISNEY PRINCESS launch, how it's gone versus your expectations and where you think we are in the license position?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Well, clearly, I think you've said one of the key words, which is clearly first quarter is a transitional quarter. We've said that all along. Having said that, the teams have done -- our teams at Hasbro have done a fantastic job of launching the br
componenttext:
:  
  Well, clearly, I think you've said one of the key words, which is clearly first quarter is a transitional quarter. We've said that all along. Having said that, the teams have done -- our teams at Hasbro have done a fantastic job of launching the brand, beautiful products. And it's been well received by consumers, and the early takeaway is quite good. We are ramping this business. And we continue to believe that as we move forward, as we expand in revenues, we'll continue to improve our operating margin over time there. So I would say that our guidance for what we want to achieve is being achieved, and we're on track for our expectations for PRINCESS.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Great. And then if we just look at STAR WARS, is there anything that you guys learned from last year's movie that you're planning to implement for this coming year's release?
componenttext:
:  
  Great. And then if we just look at STAR WARS, is there anything that you guys learned from last year's movie that you're planning to implement for this coming year's release?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Well, clearly, that was great for us to be able to have a major entertainment initiative in fourth quarter. It's great to build, to spread the entertainment initiatives across our portfolio now almost 12 months a year. And that will continue to be
componenttext:
:  
  Well, clearly, that was great for us to be able to have a major entertainment initiative in fourth quarter. It's great to build, to spread the entertainment initiatives across our portfolio now almost 12 months a year. And that will continue to be the case as we have more and more partners and our own brands launching new story-led initiatives throughout each year. The consumer certainly responded in kind, and it gives us great courage to look at new windows for new launches. And we'll track similar to last year, kind of a similar tempo and template this year as we have a fall set date for Rogue One product, and that will roll into a holiday-oriented movie. But again, the teams are constantly picking up on new insights, and we're using those to the advantage of customers and consumers.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Brian, on Girls, can you help us better understand how the segment performed, excluding the DISNEY PRINCESS piece? And then the follow-up to that, how do we think about the transition of that property into your business? Should we think of 1Q as ki
componenttext:
:  
  Brian, on Girls, can you help us better understand how the segment performed, excluding the DISNEY PRINCESS piece? And then the follow-up to that, how do we think about the transition of that property into your business? Should we think of 1Q as kind of a disproportionate beneficiary given the fact that it represents the initial shipping window for that property?

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: :    Well, if you look at it, clearly, in a quarter, where typically lower revenues, it does have a disproportional impact. As you grow throughout the year, your revenues grow across the board. We had a number of our Girls brands that performed well and
componenttext:
:  
  Well, if you look at it, clearly, in a quarter, where typically lower revenues, it does have a disproportional impact. As you grow throughout the year, your revenues grow across the board. We had a number of our Girls brands that performed well and grew in the quarter. So we saw some great growth from some of what we would call our Challenger Brands, including FurReal Friends, Baby Alive and EASY BAKE. And then MY LITTLE PONY, as I said, the brand overall was up. The only place that had an impact, where it flattens the result, is because of the streaming revenues that are assigned to the purchase of MY LITTLE PONY programming and LITTLEST PET SHOP programming a year ago. So we had one brand in there that we're restaging for the fall, which is NERF REBELLE. And clearly, the brand is down at this moment as we restage and get reoriented around that brand for the second half of the year. And again, PET SHOP had very strong results in several territories, including the U.S. and Canada. And we're beginning to make the shift, the change and evolution of that brand out internationally. And over time, we would expect that brand to see more positive momentum overall.

headline: Hasbro Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 18, 2016

componenttext:
